review_title: "New UB" under Goodwin is different. Know what you're getting into.
pros:
People are very friendly
Great, ambitious students
Leadership seems to be transparent and approachable
cons:
Bad pay. Not competitive at all (no matter what they tell you). Do your research
Worse benefits - slow 401k vesting, poor insurance options, 8.5 hour day, 2 sick days per year
Post-merger atmosphere and morale are very poor 
Slow decisions from leadership
VERY little flexibility and work life balance 
Very few vacation/holidays for a higher ed employer (no week off in December)

pros: Absolutely wonderful skilled and student-centered colleagues, collaborative and supportive faculty culture, Students are down to earth, very diverse, and largely not entitled.
cons: Decades of financial challenges and the failure of city and state government to urban renew the neighborhood around the campus, along on an over reliance on revenue from international student tuition dollars have led UB to have major financial challenges despite healthy enrollment. Faculty salaries on the low side for the region and vary widely among disciplines. Current faculty and staff are paying the price for these challenges. It is still not known what our acquisition by Goodwin University will mean for salaries and working conditions, but the available evidence skews negative.

job_title: IT Technical Director in Bridgeport, CT
pros: Some very good people work there but the good ones never seem to last.  Great for getting higher education experience.
cons: Never received a review or growth opportunities. Dealt with a culture of being "on call" 24/7 since we were all salaried employees. Constantly changing priorities made us a dept that was reactive and not proactive. Micro managing CIO with some technical ability but zero management skills. Had some great people I worked with but most were either moving on or had been worn down by UB's culture of chaos. You will be asked to do things that are unethical, huge amounts of gender bias that gets swept under the rug. If you issue a complaint, well.... don't count on HRs non-retaliation policy or you will find yourself in the same position I did. Wasteful and still heavily dominated in top tier management positions by the members of the unification church (cult)

pros: Have loved working here. Very supportive fellow faculty
cons: Closing due to Trump administration's xenophobic policies chasing away foreign students. This is prior to the pandemic.

review_title: Underpaid, overworked, and unappreciated. Only work here if you're trying to beef up your resume or be miserable.

cons: Low salaries, lack of communication between departments, too many cut throat co-workers (people who will throw you under the bus just to make themselves look better), hardly any growth opportunities (if there are any, only the kiss-ups will get the promotion)

cons: So far I have not had any negative experiences yet working there the professors are great and very helpful

job_title: Clinical Assistant Professor in Fairfield, CT
pros: Nice colleagues, generally respectful students
cons:
Over the past 3-4 years, UB has been losing money. This is a fact that can be verified by reading the Forbes magazine article "Dawn of the Dead: For Hundreds of the nations private colleges its merge or perish"
 
1.) Inferior facilities:  UB's buildings were mostly built in the 1950s and 1960s, and many of them have not been renovated to keep up with the Internet and new technologies. Some of the buildings, frankly, need to be torn down. To renovate them would cost at least $50-75 million in funds that UB does not have.

2.) Inferior teaching:  Many of the faculty at UB are part-time (60-70%) and get paid VERY low salaries ($3,000 total for one full semester = approx. less than $10 per hour). Most of the nearby colleges and universities in CT pay their part-time faculty at least $5,000 per class. This means that the BEST faculty go and teach at those other universities.  UB only has about 140 full-time faculty for nearly 5,000 students = 35 students for each full-time faculty.  Most other universities have DOUBLE that amount, meaning that the students at those schools get more attention, mentoring, and higher quality instruction. A full-time professor gets paid about $50-60,0000 per year starting, so if UB wanted to hire 140 new full-time faculty, they would need $8.4 millions dollars more each year in income. Most other colleges in CT pay higher, so the best will go somewhere else whenever they can. This has already been happening over the past 2-3 years and will continue!

3.) Inferior Services:  Most of the offices for different student services (career services, study abroad, student activities, etc.) are offices with only ONE employee.  This means that even if those employees are fantastic, they cannot keep up with all of the needs of the students.  Also, they are paid around $40,000 per year! Many of the long-time staff members at UB, like the 22-year veteran Dean of Students, were fired without cause over the past 1-2 years by the new president, meaning their loyalty to UB and expertise was also lost. That is irreplaceable

4.) Inferior finances: The University of Bridgeport has been running a $5-6 million dollar deficit for the past 3-4 years and surely will run a huge deficit this year due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Recent estimates place their losses at $12-15 millon!

5.) Inferior Alumni network: The University of Bridgeport has a VERY WEAK alumni network, for some very specific historical reasons -

 In 1990-91, UB had the longest faculty strike in the history of any college or university, leading the firing of almost all of the faculty and staff. The student body from the 1980s-early 1990s were small and many of them were ignored in the following 25 years (1991-2016) because the university almost closed and had NO  FUNCTIONAL ALUMNI OFFICE UNTIL 2016.

 UB was led by the Unification Movement, a "church" founded by Sun Yung Moon in Korea in the 1950s-1960s since 1992. The Unificationists are very loyal to Rev. Moon, who they believe is the second coming of Jesus. In the 1970s they gained a bad reputation, so when they paid $100 million to bail out UB in 1992, the majority alumni from the 1960s-1990s were NOT HAPPY, and have not supported UB ever since. The Unification movement made a deal with UB that their children could study at UB for free, but many of those unificationist alumni give their money to the church after graduation, NOT to UB.

UB alumni since 1995-2016 have been a combination of unificationists, international students, and domestic students from low-income backgrounds.  The unificationists will not donate to UB because they give to their church and now they are offended by the fact that Trombley purged them and their parents and friends from UB .  International students do not come from countries with a culture of donating money to their alumni institutions, so they do not and will not give money to UB.  Low-income domestic students often do not graduate from UB, have huge amounts of student debt, and do not gain high levels of employment, so they will not give back to UB. 

Bottom Line:

UB needs at least $60-90 million in EXTRA funding immediately just to renovate facilities and hire more staff and faculty to be competitive with peer institutions, and they need to balance the current budget and stop losing $5-6 million per year. UB's money comes almost entirely from TUITION, so if less students come (enrollment dropped every year since 2017), where is the money going to come from? International students most likely will not return in Fall 2020, and domestic enrollment is dropping.
